metadata.title: Role of Plant Growth Promoting Rhizobacteria and Ag-nano particle in the Bioremediation of heavy metals and Maize growth under Municipal wastewater irrigation

sections.text:
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 1
The investigation evaluated the role of plant growth promoting rhizobacteria (PGPR) and Ag nano particle on the growth and metabolism of maize irrigated with municipal wastewater (MW). Three PGPR isolated from MW were identified on the basis of 16S-rRNA gene sequence analyses as Pseudomonas sp., Pseudomonas fluorescence and Bacillus cereus. The municipal waste water was used to irrigate the maize seeds inoculated with 3 isolated PGPR. The isolated PGPR had catalse and oxidase enzymes, solubilize insoluble bound phosphate and exhibit antifungal and antibacterial activities. The colony forming unit (cfu) of the PGPR was inhibited by Ag-nano particle, but was stimulated by the municipal wastewater. The Ag-nano particles augmented the PGPR induced increase in root area and root length. The root-shoot ratio was also changed with the Ag-nano particles. The plants irrigated with municipal wastewater had higher activities of peroxidase and catalase which were further augmented by Ag-nano particle. The AgD ow nl oa de d by [ G az i U ni

irrigation. This aims for the better growth of the plant and enhanced bioremediation of toxic heavy metals.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The availability of fresh water is going to decrease in the year to come and drought has been predicted as the principal stress (PAK-SEC, 2006). The municipal wastewater constitutes a large share of wastewater and the total water discharged in the river (PWSS, 2002). The municipal wastewater composed of mainly phosphorous, nitrogen and organic matter, in addition to suspended and/or dissolved solids and microscopic organism (Saucedo et al., 2006). In Pakistan irrigation of 26% of total agronomic land depend on wastewater that contains local and industrial wastes (Kakar et al., 2010; Pedreroa et al. 2010) which leads to several health problems. The wastewater produced in Pakistan is frequently applied for watering of about 32,500 ha of agriculture land, in Pakistan only 8 cities have wastewater treatment facilities out of 388 cities. The municipal waste water needs prior treatment to render it usable for agriculture. Phytoremediation and bioremediation are environmental friendly and cost effective technologies aimed for this purpose. Phytoremediation is the process of using green plants for the removal of pollutants from the environment or to reduce their harmful effects. This technique can be used to remove organic as well as inorganic contaminants. It is the best technology observed in its negligible site disruption and minimal cost (Gerhardt et al., 2009; Weyens et al., 2009a). Endophytic rhizospheric microorganisms cooperate more meticulously with their host plants and may be more capable to mend the phytoremediation (Weyens et al., 2009a; Germaine et al., 2009).
Various free-living rhizospheric bacteria that promote the growth of plant can be applied in heavy metal polluted soils to alleviate lethal effects of heavy-metals on the flora (Belimov et

al., 2004). Bacillus cereus is a plant growth promoting rhizobacterium that can be used to control diverse group of pathogenic microorganisms (Niu et al., 2011). It is rod-shaped and gram positive bacterium (Ryan, 2004), growing optimally at 20°C-40°C, and is proficient to survive in extensive array of environmental circumstances (Vilain et al., 2006). Various strains of Pseudomonas fluorescence play key role in the bio-remediation of heavy metals (Ali and Ahmad, 2006). Pseudomonas sp. also exhibit vital role in the utilization of heavy metals ((Nouri et al, 2011). Some micronutrients like zinc, nickel, chromium and copper are crucial for plant and animal life as well as for micro-organisms (Olson et al., 2001) whereas, some metals (e.g. mercury, cadmium and lead) do not show any clear biotic or physiological role (Gadd, 1992). Thus microbial population either completely inhibit metal ions by inhabiting their different metabolic activities or organisms can develop tolerance mechanisms to higher concentration of metals. Growth promoting rhizobacteria have developed several mechanisms for their survival under metal-stressed environment. These include, mobilizing or transforming metals into inactive form to allow the uptake of heavy metal ions (Nies, 1999). In recent years, the development of nanoscience and nanotechnology has shown remarkable potential for the remediation of environmental problems (Lee et al., 2010, Ali, 2012).With its unique size- and shape-dependent properties, they have been broadly examined over a decade for remediation purposes (Gao et al., 2008). Ag-nano particle showed an extensive range of antimicrobial activity and assist in the control of pathogenic microorganisms (Jo et al., 2009). Nanoparticles formed by metal or metal oxides are used to remove heavy metal ions in wastewater treatment (Ali, 2012). D ow nl oa de d by [ G az i U ni ve rs ity ] at 1 1: 33 3 0 O ct ob er 2 01 5

Present research was therefore, undertaken to isolate and characterize plant growth promoting rhizobacteria from municipal wastewater collected from National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad and to study the role of isolated microbes on the bioremediation of heavy metals added from municipal wastewater. The interactive effects of Ag-nano particles on the isolated microbes and on the growth of maize as well as on the bioremediation of heavy metals have been evaluated.

sections.heading: Materials and Methods
sections.text:
Municipal wastewater was collected from municipal wastewater supply in National Agriculture Research Center, Islamabad. Municipal wastewater treatment was developed at National Agricultural Research Centre (NARC), which consist of aquatic plants in detention ponds, microbes and constructed wetland. This invaluable approach, treated municipal wastewater in the permissible range of National Environment Quality Standards (NEQ’s) (Ali et al., 2013). The municipal wastewater was colorless having pH 7.6. It contained Ca (0.25 g/kg), Ni (0.14 g/kg), Pb (0.11 g/kg), Na (0.077 k/kg), Mg (0.065 g/kg) and K (0,046 g/kg) relatively in high concentration, whereas Zn (0.0007 g/kg), Cu (0.007 g/kg), Cr (0.0009 g/kg), Cd (0.0017 g/kg) were under the permissible limits.
Isolation of bacteria, method of inoculation and plant growth
Isolation of PGPR strains were made from municipal wastewater collected from National Agricultural Research Centre (NARC), Islamabad on Luria Bertani (LB) media. The 3 microbes isolated were named as N14, N15 and N20, which were further identified by 16S-rRNA sequencing analysis.

The fresh culture (24h old) of the bacteria was used to inoculate LB broth, incubated in shaker (Excella E24, USA) for 48h, thereafter centrifuged for 10 min at 10,000 rpm. After discarding supernatant, pellet was suspended in distilled water and the optical density (at 660nm) was adjusted to be 1 which was equivalent to 10 6 cells per ml.
The experimental work was carried out in pots placed under natural condition. Seeds of Zea mays L.(advance germplasm line: Islamabad Gold) obtained from National Agriculture Research Center, Islamabad was sown in plastic pots measuring 30×40 cm² and filled with autoclaved garden soil and sand in 3:1 ratio. Prior to sowing surface sterilization of seeds was carried out by shaking in 95% ethanol for 2-3 min followed by soaking in 10% chlorox with concomitant shaking. Subsequently the seeds were washed 3-4x in autoclaved distilled water. Seeds were soaked in inoculated broth for 3-4 h prior to sowing. The number of bacterial cells present after inoculation were 1 × 10 5 per seed. Plants were irrigated every 6d with municipal wastewater (150ml/replicate). All the treatments were evaluated using completely randomized design (CRD) with four replicates.

sections.heading: Colony and Cell Morphology
sections.text: Fresh cultures obtained after 24 h of their incubation on agar plates (Miller, 1972) were used for identification of bacterial strains under microscope (Bio-Microscope XSZ-701, China).

sections.heading: Catalase and oxidase test
sections.text:
Fresh culture (24 h old) of bacteria was placed on a glass slide. One drop of H2O2 (30%) was added, presence of gas bubbles indicated the presence of catalase (McFadden, 1980).

The oxidase enzyme was detected in bacterial cell following the method of Steel (1961). Oxidase test was performed by using the Kovac’s Reagent. N,N,N,N tetramethyl-p-phenylene diamine (Kovacks, 1956). A band of filter paper was dipped in freshly prepared Kovac’s reagent and air dried. Bacterial colonies (24h old) were transferred to the small strip of filter paper. The change in color from dark purple to black indicated the presence of oxidase enzyme.

sections.heading: DNA extraction and 16S-rRNA sequence analysis
sections.text:
Extraction of genomic DNA was done from overnight grown culture of pure bacterial colony following the method of Chen and Kuo (1993) and amplified by PCR following the method described by Weisburg (1991). The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was carried out by using forward (fd1) primer having nucleotide sequences AGAGTTTGATCCTGGCTCAG and reverse (rd1) primer (AAGGAGGTGATCCAGCC). The reactions were carried out in thermocycler (Biometra, Germany). Each reaction volume (25 μL) contained 1 μL of 50 μg of genomic DNA, 1.5 mM MgCl2, 0.2 mM dNTP mix, 1 unit of Taq DNA polymerase, 5 μL of 10 X Taq buffer 10 p moles of each primer and the rest of the volume was raised by autoclaved cold water. After denaturation at 95°C for 2 min, samples were cycled for 30 rounds through the following temperature profile: denaturation at 94°C for 30 s, annealing at 55°C for 30 s, extension at 72°C for 2 min followed by incubation at 72°C for 10 min. Then (5 μl) amplified PCR products were separated by gel electrophoresis on 1.2 % (w/v) agarose gel and visualized with ethidium bromide (0.01 g/ml) under UV trans-illuminator lamp (S. N. 76S/64069, Bio RAD, Italy) and photographed. The 1kb DNA ladder (Fermentas, Germany) was used as molecular marker. The PCR product was excised from the gels and purified by using gel purification kits (jet QUICK, Gel Extraction Spin Kit, GENOMED). sections.heading: Phosphate solubilization Index
sections.text:
Pikovskaya’s media used for determining phosphate solubilization, which was poured into sterilized petri-plates under sterilized conditions; a pin point inoculation was done after solidification of agar plates. Solubilization of insoluble phosphate was indicated by halozone formation on the plate. The plates were incubated at 28 o C for 7 d. Solubilization index (SI) was calculated by the formula of Pikovskaya (1948)
SI = Colony diameter + halozone diameter/ Colony diameter
Antibacterial activity of isolated PGPR The isolated bacterial strains were evaluated for the determination of antibacterial activity following the Agar well Diffusion method (Navarro et al., 1996).
Antifungal activity of the plant growth promoting rhizobacteria
The agar tube dilution method was used for the determination of antifungal activity of plant growth promoting rhizobacteria (Washington and Suetter 1980).The following fungal strains were used in this study.

sections.heading: Assay Procedure of Antifungal Activity
sections.text:
Media for fungus was prepared by dissolving 6.5g of SDA (Sabouraud dextrose agar) (MERCK) per 100ml in distilled water and pH was adjusted at 5.6. Test tubes were marked to 10 cm. The Sabouraud dextrose agar was dispensed as 4ml volume into screw capped tubes and was autoclaved at 121°C for 21 minutes. Tubes were allowed to cool to 50 °C and non-solidified SDA was loaded with 67 μl of cell free supernatant pipette from the stock solution. This would give the final concentration of 200 μg /ml of the pure compound in media. Tubes were then allowed to solidify in slanting position at room temperature. One slant of the extract sample was prepared for each fungus species. The tubes containing solidified media and test compounds were inoculated with 4mm diameter piece of inoculum, taken from a seven days old culture of fungus. One sample of each extract was prepared, which were used for positive control. Slants without extract were used for negative control.
The test tubes were incubated at 28°C for 7 days. Cultures were examined twice weekly during the incubation. Reading was taken by measuring the linear length of fungus in slant by measuring growth (mm) and growth inhibition was calculated with reference to negative control.

sections.heading: Nutrients Analysis of Rhizospheric Soil
sections.text:
The rhizospheric soil was analyzed for macro nutrients Ca, Mg, K and Na and for heavy metals Ni, Pb and Cd following the Ammonium Bicarbonate-DTPA method developed by Soltanpour and Schwab (1977).
Nutrient Analyses of plant extracts
Oven dried leaves sample (0.25g) were taken in 50 ml flask to which 6.5 ml of mixed acid solution i.e., Nitric acid, Sulphuric acid, Perchloric acid (5:1:0.1) were added and boiled on hot plate under fume hood till the digestion has been completed which was indicated by white fumes coming out from the flasks.
Thereafter, few drops of distilled water were added and allowed to cool. The digested samples were transferred in 50 ml volumetric flasks and the volume was made up to 50ml by adding distilled water. The extract was filtered with Whatmann No. 42 filter paper and concentration of these elements was determined by Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometer (Shimadzu AA-670).
Stock solution (100 ppm) of different elements were prepared for the determination of macro and micronutrients following the method of Allen (1974).

sections.heading: Determination of IAA, GA3 and ABA
sections.text: The extraction and purification for plant hormones were made by the method of Kettner and Döerffling (1995). Fresh plant leaves (1g) were grounded at 4 0 C in 80% methanol with butylated hydroxyl toluene as an antioxidant. After 72h extraction, the pooled extract was centrifuged at 3000 rpm and the supernatant was partitioned 4x at acidic pH (2.5-3) with ethylacetate (1/4th volume of the extract) The ethyl acetate phase was dried down completely on RFE and the residue was redissolved in 100% methanol. The samples were passed through Millipore filter (0.45u) and were analyzed on HPLC (Agilent 1100) equipped with variable UV detector and C18 column (39 x 300mm) (BondaPack Porasil C18, 37/50 µm, Waters, Eschborn, BRD). Methanol and water in the ratio of (30:70; v/v) were used as mobile phase @ of 1500µl/min with a run time of 20min/sample. The growth hormones were identified on the basis of retention time of phytohormone standards. IAA and GA were eluted at 280nm and 254 nm wavelength respectively. For ABA the samples were injected onto a C18 column and eluted with a linear gradient of methanol (30-70%), containing 0.01% acetic acid, at a flow rate of 0.8 ml min -1 .

sections.heading: Extraction for antioxidant enzymes
sections.text:
For determination of antioxidant enzymes fresh leaves (500mg) was grinded in 5ml of 50mM phosphate buffer and placed in ice bath, centrifuged at 4 o C for 20 min at 13000rpm. Which was used for enzyme assay.
The method of Vetter et al., (1958) as modified by Gorin and Heidma (1976) was used for the determination of Peroxidase (POD) activity. The assay mixture contained enzyme extract (0.1ml), 1.35ul MES buffer (pH 5.5), H2O2 (0.05%) and phenylene diamine (0.1%). Change in absorbance was recorded with spectrophotometer at 485 nm (for 3min). POD activity was presented as units per g fresh weight of leaves.
For determination of Ascorbate peroxidase (APOX) activity, the procedure of Asada and Takahashi (1987) was used. The reaction mixture (1ml) consisted of potassium phosphate buffer (50 mM), ascorbic acid (0.5mM), H2O2 (0.1mM) and enzyme extract (100 µl). The absorbance was read against the black as the reduction at 290nm, modification was carried out for the low/none enzymatic oxidation of ascorbic acid by H2O2 (extinction coefficient: 2.9/mM/cm).The enzymatic activity was expressed in U/mg protein (U= change in 0.1 absorbance/min/mg of protein).
Chandlee and Scandalios (1984) method with slight modification was used for determining Catalase (CAT) activity. The assay mixture contained potassium phosphate buffer (2.6 ml of 50 mM at pH 7.0), enzyme extract (40ul) and H2O2 (400ul). The breakdown of H2O2 was indicated by drop in absorbance at 240nm.The enzymatic activity was expressed in U/mg protein (U=1mM of H2O2 reduction/ min/ mg of protein).

Viable cell count method (cfu) Decimal dilutions of Municipal waste water was made using autoclaved distilled water. An aliquot (100ul) of each dilution (100ul) was spread on plates. The plates were then incubated at 30 0 C overnight. After incubation the appeared colonies on the plates (10 -5 dilution) were counted. Viable cell counts were calculated as suggested by James (1987):
Viable cell count (CFU/g) = (number of colonies× dilution factor/volume of inoculum)
Preparation and Treatment with Ag-nano particles
The Ag-nanoparticles were prepared from stock solution of Ag nanoparticles (4%) obtained from National Centre of Physics (NCP) prepared originally by Hussain and Mahmood (2011). Ag nanoparticles was prepared by adding 30ml of 0.002M sodium borohydride (NaBH4) to an Erlenmeyer flask. This solution in flask was placed in ice bath and stirred mechanically for 20 min. Then 2ml of 0.001M silver nitrate (AgNO3) was added drop wise into NaBH4 solution at the rate of 1 drop per second. The reflection of laser beam from particles could be used for detection of colloidal suspension. The suspension turn into darker yellow and then into grey color by adding few drops of 1.5 M NaCl solution. Addition of 0.3% polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) solution prevented the accretion of Ag nanoparticles.
The diameter of Ag nanoparticles confirmed by XRD (X-ray Diffraction) varied from 4-6 nm. For preparation of 200ppm of Ag nanoparticles solution, 0.5ml of stock solution was diluted in 100ml of distilled water. The solution was further diluted to 20 ppm and applied as seeds soaking

sections.heading: Alignment of 16S rRNA sequence
sections.text:
For the isolate N14 obtained from municipal wastewater, the total length of sequence with 1474 nucleotide was obtained. The comparison of the nucleotide sequence with data nucleotide bank showed highest sequence similarity with 1472/1474 and 99% with that of Pseudomonas sp. strain (ACC No.: JQ766121.1).For the isolate N15 obtained from municipal wastewater, the total length of sequence with 1467 nucleotide was obtained. The comparison of the nucleotide sequence with data nucleotide bank showed highest sequence similarity with 1466/1467 and 99% with that of Pseudomonas fluorescence strain (ACC No.: GU198110.1).For the isolate N20 obtained from municipal wastewater, the total length of sequence with 1485 nucleotide was obtained. The comparison of the nucleotide sequence with data nucleotide bank showed highest sequence similarity with 1482/1483 and 99% with that of Bacillus cereus strain (ACC No.: CP003187.1). sections.heading: Colony Forming Unit (cfu) of Rhizosphere Soil
sections.text: The rhizosphere of plants inoculated with Pseudomonas fluorescence showed higher cfu as compared to that of Pseudomonas sp. and Bacillus cereus. Addition of municipal wastewater increased the cfu significantly even in presence of Ag-nano particle. Maximum increase was in Pseudomonas sp. and Bacillus cereus. Addition of Ag-nanoparticle alone decreased the cfu of all three isolated microbes. The rhizosphere of plants irrigated with municipal wastewater alone had cfu lesser than those inoculated with Pseudomonas sp and with Bacillus cereus or P. fluorescence (Table 2).

sections.heading: Antibacterial and Antifungal Activities of PGPR Isolates
sections.text: Pseudomonas sp. and Bacillus cereus showed activity against all the five bacterial strains i.e. Staphylococcus aureus, P. aunignda, Bacillus subtilis, Klebsiella pneumoniae and Escherichia coli. The Pseudomonas flourescence had no response against P. aunignda. Maximum inhibition (35%) of Helminthosporium sativum was observed due to Bacillus cereus Whereas, Pseudomonas sp. and Pseudomonas fluorescence were ineffective against Helminthosporium sativum. Bacillus cereus significantly inhibited the growth of Fusarium solani (90%) (Table 3).

sections.heading: Phosphate Solubilization Index
sections.text:
All the three PGPR were P-solubilizer, Bacillus cereus was the most efficient phosphorus solubilizer having phosphorus solubilization index 2.77. The phosphorus solubilization indices for Pseudomonas fluorescence and Pseudomonas sp. were 1.33 and 1.23 respectively (Table 4).

Anti-biotic resistance of selected PGPR
Bacillus cereus tolerated chloramphenicol upto 200 ug/ml. this was in contrast to Pseudomonas fluorescence and Pseudomonas sp. which failed to survive beyond 150 ul/ml. Pseudomonas sp. and Bacillus cereus can grow at 200 ug/ml streptomycin whereas, Pseudomonas fluorescence can tolerate upto 150 ug/ml. The Pseudomonas fluorescence and Bacillus cereus can grow in culture containing hygromycin B till 150 ug/ml but Pseudomonas sp. cannot survive beyond 25 ug/ml (Table 5).
Heavy metal accumulation in soil and shoot of maize
The Pb accumulation was increased in plants inoculated with Bacillus cereus. The treatment with Ag-nano particle and municipal wastewater increased the accumulation of Pb and Ni in both Pseudomonas sp. and Pseudomonas fluorescence inoculated plants but the rhizosphere soil of Bacillus cereus inoculated plants had Ni content similar to control. Similar was the case with Agnano particle (T1) which has increased the Ni accumulation to maximum of 90% but addition of municipal wastewater slightly decreased the accumulation of Ni in soil by 30% concomitant with the increase in Pb accumulation by 41% over T1 (Fig 1).
The plants treated with municipal wastewater and the Ag-nano particle treatment (T1) enhanced Pb accumulation in plants but the combined treatment was more stimulatory. Ag-nano particle in presence of municipal wastewater and Pseudomonas fluorescence also enhanced the Ni accumulation in plants. But the PGPR treatments alone and in presence of Ag-nano particle and municipal wastewater decreased the Cd accumulation by 7% over T1 (Fig 2).

Macronutrients accumulation in soil and shoot of maize
Ag-nano particle had increased the K, Mg and Na content in soil. The K content was higher than Na and Mg contents except inoculation treatment with Bacillus cereus. Ag-nano particle alone and in presence of municipal wastewater increased the K content over Na. No difference was recorded in the Ca content of control and municipal wastewater treated plants whereas, the K and Mg contents were higher in the latter. The Pseudomonas fluorescence and Bacillus cereus inoculations increased the Ca content of plants significantly over municipal wastewater and Agnano particle, the latter being most effective. Some PGPR showed varied response to Ag-nano particles. Pseudomonas fluorescence showed increase in Ca and K contents whereas, Bacillus cereus showed decrease in Ca content (Fig 3).
The Ag-nano particle had suppressed the PGPR-induced increase in Ca content. No significant difference was recorded in the K content over Ag-nano particle or municipal wastewater treatments. The Ag-nano particle in presence of municipal wastewater decreased the K but increased the Ca content of plants. All the 3 PGPR, Ag-nano particle and municipal wastewater had higher Na accumulation (Fig 4).

Ag-nano particle alone had no effect on root, shoot length, leaf and root area as compared to that of municipal wastewater treated plants. Chlorophyll and Carotenoids contents of leaves
The chlorophyll content was not significantly affected among the treatments except T6, T7 and T10. However, municipal wastewater treatment (T12) had higher chlorophyll content. The Agnano particle had no significant effect on chlorophyll content and the same was maintained in T2 (Pseudomonas sp.) and Pseudomonas sp. + Ag-nano particle (T8). The carotenoids content showed variable results. It was higher in all the treatments. The Ag-nano particle either alone or in presence of municipal wastewater decreased the carotenoids content (Fig 6).
Antioxidant enzymes and proline content
Treatment with municipal wastewater increased the POD activities (93%) higher than the untreated control. The inoculation with Pseudomonas fluorescence and Bacillus cereus increased the POD and catalase activities of maize leaves. The response of PGPR to Ag-nano particle spray on maize was variable. The Ag-nano particle increased the POD and catalase activities of Pseudomonas sp. and Bacillus cereus inoculated plant leaves by 93% and 94% over control but in presence of municipal wastewater, the Ag-nano particle and PGPR had decreased the catalase

sections.heading: Phytohormones in leaves
sections.text: In presence of municipal wastewater and PGPR the GA content of leaves was lowered than that of Ag-nano particle (T1) but the ABA content showed variable result, it was decreased to basal (control) level in Pseudomonas sp. inoculation (T2) but was higher in P. fluorescence (T3) and Bacillus cereus (T4) treatments. Silver nanoparticle significantly enhanced the IAA, GA and ABA content as compared to all other treatments (Fig 8).

sections.text:

Pseudomonas fluorescence and Bacillus cereus may be attributed to the presence of organic matter in the municipal wastewater which served as C/N source for the PGPR isolates. Similar results were presented by Yongabi et al., (2011) that polluted water contains high concentration of micro-organisms. Dhevagi and Oblisami (2002) demonstrated that wastewater contains heavy metals and also nutrients which affect plant and soil on a variety of ways.
Both the PGPRs and Ag-nano particle enhanced the Pb and Ni accumulation in the rhizosphere soil and plants. The PGPR Bacillus cereus being most effective. Ag-nano particle augmented the effect of PGPR. The 2 PGPR Bacillus cereus and Pseudomonas fluorescence had higher Na over K in soil also have higher Ca, the effect of Ag-nano particle was to decrease Na over K keeping the Ca higher. When applied in combination with the PGPR, Ag-nano particle decreased Na and Ca contents but increased the K content. Similar results were recorded by Lee et al. (2008) which demonstrate that Ag-nano particle assist in translocation of heavy metals. Chen et al., (2010) investigated the resistant ability of four endophytic bacteria to heavy metals and found that these bacteria enhanced Cd-accumulation in stem, root and leaf tissues of Solanum nigrum L. grown in three different levels of Cd contaminated soil and the accumulation ability was altered with the Cd concentration in the soil. The metal resistant endophytes increased the concentration of respective metals in plant tissues (Mastretta et al., 2009). Sheng et al., (2008b) reported that inoculated Brassica napus with endophytic, Pb-resistant bacteria can amplify the uptake of Pb in the shoot of the plant. Pseudomonas sp. and Acinetobacter have shown to increase phytoremediation skills of non hyperaccumulating maize by increasing biomass and their growth (Lippmann et al., 1995). The PGPR induced increase in growth parameters in the inoculated treatments had been reported earlier (Sajid et al., 2006). These isolates appear stimulatory to root, shoot length and root area but the antagonistic effect of Ag-nano particle was observed on the PGPR induced root and shoot length. Stampoulis et al., (2009) observed that the application of Ag-nanoparticles on zucchini plants in hydroponic solution showed no negative effects but reduced plant biomass and transpiration.
It was inferred that due to higher nutrient content in municipal wastewater, the chlorophyll content was increased in the municipal wastewater treated plants. Ag-nano particle appeared to reduce carotenoids content. In osmoregulation the municipal wastewater treatment did not play any role; on the other hand the Ag-nano particle alone was stimulatory to proline production though it had suppressed the promotory effect of PGPR on proline production. The higher activities of antioxidant enzymes POD and catalase in municipal wastewater treatment is indication of the oxidative stress encountered by the plants irrigated with municipal wastewater. Results demonstrated that Ag-nano particle further augmented the activities of antioxidant enzymes. The lack of any significant effect on these enzymes by PGPR treatment except that of Bacillus cereus may be attributed to the fact that the oxidative stress was encountered by the PGPR and further enhancement in the antioxidant enzymes was not required. However, greater decrease in the activities of these enzymes by Ag-nano particle in presence of PGPR may account for further amelioration of oxidative stress and needs further investigation. Plants also protect themselves from metal toxicity in metal stressed soils by producing antioxidant enzymes that can act as scavenger for the toxicity of reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced by plants (Cardoso et al., 2005) and/or by bacteria (Corticeiro et al., 2006). The presence of higher ABA content in Ag-nano particle treated plants indicated the presence of stress hormone,ABA mediated tolerance encountered by Ag-nano particle application but at the same time the GA content was increased which may account for augmented water and nutrient uptake from the municipal wastewater used for irrigation and that is reflected in less osmoregulation production in presence of Ag-nano particle. The PGPR interaction with Ag-nano particle showed variable response. Bacillus cereus had ABA higher but its IAA and GA production ability was suppressed by Ag-nano particle, perhaps Bacillus cereus has also decreased ability of osmoregulation as evidenced by less proline content and also the lower magnitude of increase in growth parameters of plant i.e. root, shoot length and area but with Pseudomonas sp. Ag-nano particle was less inhibitory in modulating the endogenous level of growth promoting hormones e.g. IAA and GA and the ABA in treated plants.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
Municipal wastewater need to be treated with PGPR isolates in order to synergize the activities of PGPR isolates therein. Ag-nano particle though suppresses the growth promoting potential of PGPR but increases their bioremediation potential for Pb, Cd and Ni. The Ag-nano particle enhanced root area and root length by PGPR isolates. Ag-nano particle is also important to encounter oxidative and osmotic stresses. D ow nl oa de d by [

metadata.abstractText: The investigation evaluated the role of plant growth promoting rhizobacteria (PGPR) and Ag nano particle on the growth and metabolism of maize irrigated with municipal wastewater (MW). Three PGPR isolated from MW were identified on the basis of 16S-rRNA gene sequence analyses as Pseudomonas sp., Pseudomonas fluorescence and Bacillus cereus. The municipal waste water was used to irrigate the maize seeds inoculated with 3 isolated PGPR. The isolated PGPR had catalse and oxidase enzymes, solubilize insoluble bound phosphate and exhibit antifungal and antibacterial activities. The colony forming unit (cfu) of the PGPR was inhibited by Ag-nano particle, but was stimulated by the municipal wastewater. The Ag-nano particles augmented the PGPR induced increase in root area and root length. The root-shoot ratio was also changed with the Ag-nano particles. The plants irrigated with municipal wastewater had higher activities of peroxidase and catalase which were further augmented by Ag-nano particle.
